Causality and Motion || Motion in General
1.1 Motion in General

There is a large body of medieval literature which deals with general
change of state: it is important because it led to a great deal of
careful analysis of continuous change (under the heading of “intension
and remission of forms”), and this body of analysis was one of the
contributing currents which led to the invention of the calculus in
the sixteenth century. So, we can look at this literature from two
viewpoints: either from the tradition which it grew out of –
that of interpretations on Aristotle’s Physics and the
picture of change found there – or from the viewpoint of what it
led to, that is, the analysis of continuous change. Either viewpoint
can be regarded as doing violence to the historical material, either
by disregarding what was new in it, or by isolating the innovation
from the tradition.

First we can look at the starting point. There
was a great deal of argument, in the thirteenth
and fourteenth century, about the precise interpretation of 
Aristotle’s theory of change: this theory talks about the bringing
about of change, by an agent, in a patient, and, furthermore, 
it talks about the change happening because of the transmission of a form 
from the agent to the patient.  The key text for this is 
Aristotle, Physics III, cc2–3 (202a9–20), and it is very obscure. 
Because of this obscurity, there is room for a good deal of disagreement
about the details: see (Löwe 2017) for a particularly baroque example. 

Next we can look at study of intension and remission of forms: (Goubier and
Roques 2017) is a good recent collection of work on this, Sylla (1982) shows
how this work was related to, and to some extent originated in, disputations 
about logic, and Dumont (2009) 
shows how these debates were related to their theological context. We must not 
forget, though, that modern scholarship on this topic
goes back to at least Anneliese Maier (1964), whose work goes back to the
1930s, and that she was working in the tradition of Pierre Duhem. So there is
a vast body of work on this topic, written by people with a variety
of agendas. Despite this, it is a very interesting body of literature, 
and, if it might seem impossibly complex, it is thus because it reflects
the variety of medieval and early modern viewpoints on this material. 

Motions are, in Aristotle’s physics, classified into
natural and violent. A paradigmatic example of
natural (local) motion is the motion of a freely falling body, whereas
an example of violent (local) motion would be the motion of a thrown
body. The motion of a falling body is natural because
a heavy body has a natural tendency to move
downwards, or, as the thirteenth-century philosopher Peter of
Auvergne puts it, “being below is the principal end
of a heavy body” (Trifolgi 2015, p. 93).
